qas.question: Who had the right to grant powers to a magistrate?
What is considered to be the most authoritative constitutional power?
What did the constitutional power of imperium grant a magistrate?

answers.text: authority to command a military force

qas.question: What would be one of the duties that a newly elected magistrate could expect to perform?
What power was in possession of every single magistrate in Rome?

context: Each republican magistrate held certain constitutional powers. Only the <a0_0>People of Rome<a0_0/> (both plebeians and patricians) had the right to confer these powers on any individual magistrate. The most powerful constitutional power was <a1_0>imperium<a1_0/>. Imperium was held by both consuls and praetors. Imperium gave a magistrate the <a2_0>authority to command a military force<a2_0/>. All magistrates also had the <a4_0>power of coercion<a4_0/>. This was used by magistrates to maintain public order. While in Rome, all citizens had a judgement against coercion. This protection was called provocatio (see below). Magistrates also had both the power and the duty <a3_0>to look for omens<a3_0/>. This power would often be used to obstruct political opponents.
